questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is investigating an OSPF issue reported by the Cisco DNA Assurance Center. Which action resolves the issue?

comments.content:
no, that's there to throw you off. it says:
"If the neighbor is in the init state check if there's authentication"

Our neighbor is not in init

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
if you accurate your vision, you look in bottom of the image, the reason of failed: authentication mismatch

ExStart: This indicates that the OSPF routers are in the initial stage of establishing an adjacency and have begun the process of exchanging information. If there is an authentication mismatch, they will not proceed beyond this state.

Selected Answer: A
A is corerct

Selected Answer: A
Correct. Check the state.

Selected Answer: A
The most common reason for the neighbours to be stuck in Exstart/Exchange state is an MTU mismatch on the OSPF-enabled interfaces between the two neighbours

choices.C: One of the neighbor links is down. Bring the interface up by running shut and no shut.
choices.B: One of the interfaces is using the wrong authentication. Match interface authentication on both links.
choices.A: One of the interfaces is using the wrong MTU. Match interface MTU on both links.
choices.D: An ACL entry blocking multicast on the interfaces. Allow multicast through the interface ACL.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is corerct

Selected Answer: D
Correct answer is D

Selected Answer: D
The key is "Translates the customer". Answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
The router that translates the customer routing information into VPNv4 routes to exchange VPNv4 routes with other devices through MP-BGP is the Provider Edge (PE) router

Selected Answer: A
The router that translates the customer routing information into VPNv4 routes to exchange VPNv4 routes with other devices through MP-BGP is the Provider Edge (PE) router1. So, the correct answer is D. PE. The PE router exchanges routing updates with the Customer Edge (CE) device, translates the CE routing information into VPNv4 routes, and exchanges these VPNv4 routes with other PE devices through the Multiprotocol Border Gateway Protocol (MP-BGP)1.

comments.content: you selected A as response. Yes, Its D.

questions.question_text: Which router translates the customer routing information into VPNv4 routes to exchange VPNv4 routes with other devices through MP-BGP?

An engineer received a ticket about a router that has reloaded. The monitoring system graphs show different traffic patterns between logical and physical interfaces when the router is rebooted. Which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Given answer is correct. Per cisco book page 882. It is supported in the Global config mode.

Selected Answer: A
"snmp ifindex" syntax is not valid in global-config mode, only in if-config.

Selected Answer: D
D is corerct

Selected Answer: D
.... " logical and physical interfaces "

crap, I'm going back to voting for D now, since placing on each interface would not make much sense.

Selected Answer: A
....So just looking at the reference from "d740f62"
"snmp-server ifindex persistence" = global command
"snmp ifindex persistence" = command from interface

D - is trying to use the interface command globally.
A - seems right.

Selected Answer: D
the SNMP ifIndex persistence feature provides an interface index (ifIndex) value that is retained and used when the switch reboots. Should be D

Selected Answer: D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst6500/ios/12-2SY/configuration/guide/sy_swcg/snmp_if_index_persistence.pdf

comments.content:
good catch, but which action resolves this issue (if the router is reloaded again)?
I go with D. I hope they are not being that petty.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
If OID has changed they should be synchronized i guess. Also the question is not to prevent this issue in near future. I guess C is best here.

choices.B: Clear the logical interfaces with snmp ifindex clear command.
choices.A: Configure the snmp ifindex persist command on the physical interfaces.
choices.D: Configure the snmp ifindex persist command globally.
choices.C: Trigger a new snmpwalk from the monitoring system to synchronize interface OIDs.

choices.A: Add ipv6 dhcp server MY_POOL under the interface ethernet 0/0 on H1.
choices.D: Add ipv6 dhcp server MY_POOL under the interface ethernet 0/0 on R1.
choices.C: Configure FF02::1:2 to discover all IPv6 DHCP clients.
choices.B: Remove FE80::A8BB:CCFF:FE00:5000 assigned by the IPv6 DHCP server.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
"ipv6 dhcp server interface command is necessary to enable the interface to use the DHCP pool for handing out IPv6 addressing information."

Selected Answer: D
D is corerct

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. After the network administrator rebuilds the IPv6 DHCP server, clients are not getting the IPv6 address lease. Which action resolves the issue?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The SNMP server with IP address 172.16.4.4 cannot access host router A. Which configuration command on router A resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
itÂ´s B

Selected Answer: B
If i'm not wrong, 172.16.4.0 0.0.0.3 is 172.16.0.0 - 172.16.0.3 => 172.16.0.4 isn't covered

Selected Answer: B
Why letter A ? 
The question is about standard access list, there isn't need wildcard mask when use the keyword host, see:

RouterA(config)#access-list 4 permit host 172.16.4.4 ?
 log Log matches against this entry
 <cr>

RouterA(config)#access-list 4 permit host 172.16.4.4
RouterA(config)#

comments.content:
HeyCarvalho, i tried as well, seems to work without the "host" statement:
Router(config-std-nacl)#permit 10.0.0.1 ?
 A.B.C.D Wildcard bits
 log Log matches against this entry
